ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about classifiers and ASL grammar.
Learned so much more about the language and about Deaf culture
I feel like I learned everything from 110, but actually learned it this time. Also a ton about narratives.

As a continuation of ASL 110, this course continued to develop and explore related aspects of American Sign Language (ASL) and Deaf Culture. In this course, we specifically focused on syntax and other elements that build a comprehensive signer that does not solely include knowing "sign words". Some aspects included a more in-depth look at classifiers, visual vernacular, and facial expressions. In addition, we focused on different elements that build Deaf Culture and Deaf Space.
I learned how to provide directions, storytelling elements, DeafSpace, and improved my receptive and expressive skills.

I learned about proper communication in sign language and an insight into deaf culture. I was also able to learn about different forms of storytelling in ASL and I learned how to convey these stories in a proper way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I liked the structure of the class and lessons we learned. I think there could be more clear communication on midterm and final project requirements, since I find it difficult to know what all the requirements are.
The service projects are a great way to practice signing, but was sometimes confusing.
i like the class as is
I enjoyed the service project and group work in this class. However, I wish it would have been more organized when it came to receiving feedback on exams and quizzes.

Conlin is a strength, great instructor. 

The organization of the projects could be a lot better.

Strengths - service project that helps one connect to the New Haven Deaf community. The teachers are Deaf, so you only communicate in ASL, which helps with language retention.

Weakness - pen pal, it was hard to set up times to
meet with them with the busyness of the week.

I feel that this course was good at making sure that all students in the class were properly involved and that everyone had a chance to communicate and ask questions. As for weaknesses, I don't think there are any glaring ones, to improve this course I would recommend that the teachers continue to keep doing what they are doing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes because you gain access to a kind and accepting community.
yes!!! i love the ASL department, and the professors are so amazing!!!
It's the best language by far, and a ton of fun. Not a gut imo, but a very solid class.

Regardless of taking this for the language requirement, I recommend this class. ASL 120 is a great way to continue growing into a strong signer. The course does so in a way that is both intellectually interesting and very fun.
Yes, I feel that ASL isn't extremely hard to jump into to learn and this class makes learning a new language fun and engaging.
